text: <@U027T1BTXMK> has joined the channel

So it's interesting the affect "random" variation can have psychologically. You can think blimey this strategy is just awful...but you could just be looking at random variation.
I suspect knowing what might expect in terms of drawdown and amplitude of noise in a strategy helps.
To say the least I was looking at my current down trend thinking crap! When it's hopefully just normal variation.

text: So backtested 2months and 6000markets, and assesed hi,lo, max drawdown to start with, gives a rough idea. But an evaluation of the normal distribution of profits and evaluating the SD would give a 95% probability of something or other...

text: Although it's not really my thing I think a MC simulation might give you a better idea of what kind of ups and downs to expect if you want to go that way. Personally I would just use common sense.

elements.text: Although it's not really my thing I think a MC simulation might give you a better idea of what kind of ups and downs to expect if you want to go that way. Personally I would just use common sense.

text: The real question isn't what type of 'drawdown' (hate that word) to expect, it's; _"how likely is it that this strategy is good given that I'm losing money"_. You might ask yourself how someone else would address answering that question.

elements.text: The real question isn't what type of 'drawdown' (hate that word) to expect, it's;
"how likely is it that this strategy is good given that I'm losing money"
. You might ask yourself how someone else would address answering that question.

text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> The first thing I'd suggest doing is verifying the accuracy of your backtest. And understanding all differences between live and backtest performance. If you do that, you can then launch strategies with a high degree of confidence even if they hit an initial downswing

elements.text: The first thing I'd suggest doing is verifying the accuracy of your backtest. And understanding all differences between live and backtest performance. If you do that, you can then launch strategies with a high degree of confidence even if they hit an initial downswing

text: I prefer using the t-test, instead of MC. It doesn't work too well when the odds are very large or small, but it's good enough for me

text: Ah you've got ages. Years probably.

text: In my experience (more than a decade at this) you don't suddenly get caught. Markets evolve but not faster than you can adapt to them. Obvious exceptions for new technology or whatever but in the normal run of things it all stays quite still.

elements.text: In my experience (more than a decade at this) you don't suddenly get caught. Markets evolve but not faster than you can adapt to them. Obvious exceptions for new technology or whatever but in the normal run of things it all stays quite still.

text: You do get ups and downs but when you stand back with a bit of distance they're never anything.

elements.text: You do get ups and downs but when you stand back with a bit of distance they're never anything.

text: I hope that's true for me, it's not going to be true for my competitors :wink:

elements.text: I hope that's true for me, it's not going to be true for my competitors

text: I don't know - maybe. Then again maybe your competitors aren't who you think they are or maybe thy don't even exist in the way you imagine. I've always wondered about my competitors - have I pushed anyone out of business? There must be new players who've come along during my 'career' and done well but they haven't eaten my lunch yet. These days I don't fear competition really at all, only big theme threats like declining betting. I was lucky to get an early jump on TPD and always assumed that I'd see it diminish when more people got involved but even that hasn't really happened. It's tempting to imagine you're competing with experts but often we're just swiping the value bets that a mug would have got by accident, most of us are only extracting a tiny proportion of traded volume so there's plenty of that to go round.

text: Why? Why not a fan? Bootstrapping reveals shape of distributions and more importantly the length of that dreaded left tail, which tells me “how likely is this strategy good”. I think drawdown (and distribution thereof) is a good metric to have, unless you have an unlimited bank then don’t bother.

elements.text: Why? Why not a fan? Bootstrapping reveals shape of distributions and more importantly the length of that dreaded left tail, which tells me “how likely is this strategy good”. I think drawdown (and distribution thereof) is a good metric to have, unless you have an unlimited bank then don’t bother.

text: From the standpoint of minimising premium charges (not that I'm anywhere near that), is it better to let your bets ride so that your wins and losses are larger, or better to close out so that you only pay commission on the net win?

elements.text: From the standpoint of minimising premium charges (not that I'm anywhere near that), is it better to let your bets ride so that your wins and losses are larger, or better to close out so that you only pay commission on the net win?

text: The trade off to letting it ride is you're already paying higher commission on your wins than you would if you closed out, so any savings in premium charge has to take that into account

elements.text: The trade off to letting it ride is you're already paying higher commission on your wins than you would if you closed out, so any savings in premium charge has to take that into account

text: <@U01S1VB9X9P> closing out can slightly reduce your edge, for example by moving bsp against your favour with your closing out bet. Obviously how much this is the case depends on your own volume compared to the volume on that runner. So from an EV perspective, its best to fill up all the premium charge in commission by letting your bets ride, after that theoretically closing out becomes a good option. However, from what i ve read here a lot of ppl (like <@U4H19D1D2>) seem to live by a "never close out" approach. Maybe its the smartest thing to do, maybe they just need the kick of the variance :smile:

text:
I focus on profit, which of course means not placing random -ev bets :wink: 

I ignore PC, at the end of the day it’s a tax, many spend a lot of time trying to reduce it but surely it’s better to spend time chasing 60% rather than clawing away at a very limited 40%?

text:
You deleted your message :joy:

But to answer your question I think its fine to hedge when starting off (yes I have changed my tune) however if you start going below the 20% lifetime then I would think about trying to pay more commission/maximising your profit by taking only value. Do you know what your lifetime comm percentage is?
